title.narrative: Responding to HIV and AIDS in Somalia

description.narrative: This is a cross-cutting project whose focus is to build national capacities of government at all levels, and civil society, to support a coordinated and effective response to the HIV & AIDS epidemic.

title.narrative: HIV and AIDS Approved Project AWP 2015
UNDP HIV Project Quarterly Report April June 2015 FINAL Copy 24 08 15

description.narrative: Management and Coordination of UNDP supported HIV/AIDS activities in Somalia
independent political entity
Health - policy, planning and administration
20,000 people to be reached through HIV Behaviour Change project (Community Conversations on HIV and HIV Radio message campaign) by end 2015

comment.narrative: At the end of 2015 approximately 11,000 people had been reached through Community Conversations on HIV
Approximately 10,000 people reached with correct information on HIV and AIDS through Community Conversations on HIV being supported in HIV ‘Hot Spots’ and via 3 radio stations in Somalia

In Q2 745 (F: 581, M: 164) people participated in Community Conversation sessions on HIV, . In Q2 HIV radio massages broadcasted through local radio stations in the three zones (Radio Hargaisa, Radio SBC, Radio Mogadish, Radio Baidoa and Radio Garowe), the number of HIV massages aired were 1,362 massages., The overall listenership of these radios is estimated to be between 3 to 5 million people in FL, Somaliland and Puntland,

1. Oversight committees conducting missions. 2. NFP Research office and Library established with UNDP support 3. No. of priority laws of NFP 5th session approved.

1. Three oversight missions conducted by Somaliland HoR Committees of Discipline, Socials affairs and Public accountss. 2. Library and research office established. Two Trainings delivered to NFP Committee Staff on legislative analysis and drafting. 3. 5 priority legislation review supported. In NFP, support to revision of 3 priority legislation is ongoing: Procurement law, Counter-Terrorism Law and Anti-Money Laundering Law. In Somaliland, 2 legislation supported: the Administrative Law bill, and Budget Act Bill

description.narrative: The project works towards an efficient, effective, professional civilian police service that meets the requirements for community policing and the needs and expectations of all Somalis; In particular, supporting accountability and oversight mechanisms.

Increased numbers of police officers; Implementation of SPF Hiring, Training and Deployment Plan. Adherence to UN and international requirements for stipends payments. Increased regional coverage into new areas.

comment.narrative: Somali Police Force to meet the basic requirements of safety and security of the citizens of Somalia.

description.narrative: 2.4.2.1 Number of legal professionals that have received training on sexual and gender-based violence 2.4.2.2 Number of citizens receiving legal aid, disaggregated by gender 2.4.2.3 Number of legal aid centre’s supported 2.4.2.4 Number of cases fully adjudicated in court, disaggregated by criminal and civil cases 2.4.2.5 Number of rape and SGBV cases, disaggregated by dismissals and convictions 2.4.3.1 Level of sample judicial written decisions justifying outcomes based on legal reasoning in accordance with international and national rights frameworks, and other constitutional and legal reforms is “high”, “medium “, or “low”

comment.narrative: Judicial staff are too few, especially women and are lacking in qualification. Somalis, especially women, remain unequal before the law. Legal traininng, including judge's training, is available throughout Somalia. Bar associations are in place in SOuth Central, Somaliland and Puntland. No UNDP supported legal clinics in South Central, but legal aid centres run by NGOs exist in some cases. 1 legal clinic in Somaliland and 1 legal aid centre in Puntland. Poor awareness of human rights and mechanisms for redress.
This project ID is now closed. Activities have successfully transitioned into the new Joint Rule of Law programme.

provider-org.narrative: UN DEPT OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS
UN DEPT OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS

description.narrative: Number of Land Use Policies and implementation roadmaps developed that support sustainable Natural Resources Management

comment.narrative: Land use policies and proper enforcement mechanisms on land-use do not exist in all zones of Somalia. This has led to conflicts over natural resources and exacerbated tensions between grazing nomadic pastoralists and sedentary agro-pastoralists. Rural populations are also using land in an ad-hoc manner, cutting trees to produce charcoal and encroaching on grazing lands.
A Land Use Policy in each zone (Somaliland, Puntland and South Central) is initiated

0 Concept notes prepared by the relevant government institutions in Puntland and Somaliland were approved and implementation of activities commenced to develop land use policies. South-Central regions to be covered through the Federal government in third quarter of 2015.

description.narrative: Output 1: - # of reconciliation conferences organized by IRAs/FGS - IRAs charters drafted through community/representatives consultation and feedback process - % of Women participating in reconciliation process/forums Output 2: Boundaries & Federation Commission (BFC) formation act is endorsed in parliament - % of women in BFC - % of members receive office equipment and tools to work - Refurbish and provide office equipment and tools for BFC office operation and support - Number of BFC members trained on framework and policy on Boundary and Federalism process. Output 3: - % of IRAs target population receive good governance and federalism messages - # of workshop/seminars/conferences conducted. Output 4: # of TA provided to MOIFA - % of Federal directorate receive office equipment support - # of MOIFA staff receive basic training to support federalism - # of Federal- interim consultative meets organized Output 5: % of Interim Regional Administration(IRA) receiving capacity building support - % of IRA staff trained in core functions area on basic service delivery process

comment.narrative:
Output 1: - At least two Reconciliation Conferences conducted towards state building process - Charters Drafted for each IRAs Output 2: - BFC is established based on FGS provisional constitution. - 20% women are members in BFC - 90% of BFC members receive required office equipment and tools to function Output 3: -In all IRAs good governance and federalism messages are broadcasted - At least two workshops/conferences are conducted. - One Regional development plan per IRA is developed. Output 4: - At least 35 MOIFA staff trained on governance and federalism - At least 6 consultative Meetings organized inclusive of PSG1 in regions - 70% of Federal directorate receive office equipment support
Output 5: - All four IRAs receive capacity building support. - 70% of IRA officials trained in basic management functions - Selected IRAs offices are rehabilitated

comment.narrative: 1. Master Plan for review support prepared and agreed. 2. 5 Regional and 1 National Dialogue Conference Undertaken 3. description.narrative: Parliament Project
Elections - elections

comment.narrative: 1. Three oversight missions conducted by Somaliland HoR Committees of Discipline, Socials affairs and Public accountss. Regional authorities and services contacted to investigate on security situation (Togdheer Region), enquire on provison of health and education services (Awadal), and the level of transparency and accountability at customs and revenue collection points to investigate (Awadal and Sanaag regions). 2. 640 MPs and their staff trained on developing agenda, parliamentary functions, orders of business etc. 3. A workshop on communication and outreach skills of MPs and constituency office staff 25 (M: 24 F: 1) conducted in Hargeisa. Using the skills gained during the first two days of the workshop, participants developed individual outreach action plans for each constituency office.

description.narrative: Electoral Assistance

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

title.narrative: PSG 13 Elections Joint Programme Final for Signature Rev 2

description.narrative: SUPPORT TO THE INCLUSIVENESS AND TRANSPARENCY OF THE ELECTORAL PROCESS
Elections - elections

1. Establishment of NIEC as a credible and capable government institution able to plan and conduct electoral operations in Somalia 2. The legal framework for electoral processes is in place 3. A 2016 electoral process (Parliament renewal) is developed and implemented 4. A coordination mechanism is in place between Government, UN, donors and electoral assistance providers to focused, effective and coherent international electoral assistance delivery

comment.narrative: 1. No recent history of national electoral processes in the Federal Republic of Somalia (no NIEC) 2. No legal framework in place for elections 3. Political ambiguity regarding upcoming national electoral processes (2016-2020). 4. A number of international electoral assistance providers are currently supporting the Federal government of Somalia and improved coordination is required

1. Appointment of NIEC Commissioners, physical establishment in place, institutional capacity development started 2. NIEC Law is passed 3. National Consultative Process is launched 4. Systematic coordination between electoral partners and stakeholders (Gov, donors, UN, electoral assistance providers)

1. NIEC Commissioners have been appointed in July 2015. Through UNDP support, (temporary) offices have been established and equipment provided; capacity development efforts initiated (strategic planning, organizational development, electoral knowledge building). (NIEC Institutional Planning Workshops in Aug and October, BRIDGE training provided to MOIFA officials in August). 2. The NIEC Law has been passed by Parliament in February 2015. 3. On 19-21 September 2015, the National Consultative Process was launched. Between October and December, around 3,000 Somalis participated in national and regional consultative forums all over the country and in Nairobi for the diaspora to discuss an electoral option for the 2016 transition of federal parliament and state. 4. UNDP was strongly involved in coordination mechanisms with electoral partners and donors together with the NIEC during specific coordination sessions (Oct 2015) as well as (bi)monthly PSG1 (sub)working meetings on coordination of electoral processes.

description.narrative: Alternative Livelihoods to Piracy in Somalia - Phase III
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Construction of Health Center; Job Market Survey Capacity Development for Local Authority Counter Piracy Awareness Campain

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration
Increase in incomes, employment and diversified livelihood assets.

comment.narrative: 43% of Somalis live on less than $1/day, and 73% less than $2/day, unemployment stands at 48% and 80% of Somali households rely on natural resource-dependent activities for their livelihoods.

Increased levels of income of 200 youth and women through provision of skills training, start-up tools and micro-grants, reduced levels of unemployment through provision of short term employment for at least another 650 youth and women involved in infrastructure rehabilitation works, as well as declining percentage of Somali households relying on natural resource-dependent activities such as charcoal burning.

comment.narrative: High levels of unemployment in direct project area due to low skills and modest investments.

At least three employment creation interventions undertaken (not more than one per community). - At least 400 youth and women (320 men and 80 women) benefited for short term jobs At least 100 people (60 men and 40 women benefited from medium and permanent job opportunities

title.narrative: Strengthening Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment

description.narrative: Strengthening Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment in Somalia

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

description.narrative: Gender Equality & Women's Empo

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

provider-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia
United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

description.narrative: 1. Number of regions that adopt quota system for women 2. Number of women that contest in national elections supported by UNDP. 3. Number of electoral policies that mainstream gender equality

comment.narrative: 1. No quotas for women in all 3 regions. 2. Data on women candidates for electoral offices at national level not available 3. No gender mainstreamed electoral policies
At least 5 media stories on women in the private sector 10 private sector companies advocated adopting gender-sensitive policies and recruiting women.

The media training on Gender was held in Uganda from 14th to 17th September.The media training on gender aims to equip key leaders of media industry ( journalists, reporters and media owners) in different regions, 11 from Federal Government, 15 from Puntland and 3 from Somaliland to a better understanding of gender equality issues in media reporting and strengthen their ability to investigate and develop reports and stories on gender and women’s issues Somali Women entrepreneurs were supported to participate in the Somali Investment Forum in Nairobi from the 8th to 10th March 2015. The event brought together Somali entrepreneurs, investors, sector experts, business development experts and other stakeholders – all of whom are focused on Somalia – to discuss Somali investing and seeks to catalyze business growth by bringing Diaspora investor and entrepreneurs and other stakeholders together to engage in a series of practical call to action events. There has been specific session on Women Entrepreneurs structured along the study on the role of women in the private sector recommendations commissioned by UNDP in 2014. UNDP GEWE has been privileged to present the findings of the private sector study. Gender project conducted meetings with 30 women from CSOs to explore the best strategies of promoting gender parity in the Somalia CO and recommended to reconvene after 6 months to measure the progressive of gender parity in Somalia and how the insights of these meetings are being applied by UNDP in order to ensure 50/50 gender parity in its staff. The follow up meeting will be held in Q3 to review the progressive change of gender parity in UNDP staff. In Puntland and Somaliland, the project continued to support young women tertiary scholarship recipients (30 in PL and 29 SL). Tuition fees, transportation and text book allowances were provided to the students to peruse the first semester of their third academic year.
At federal level, the Ministry of Education was enga

description.narrative: - Systems in place to allocate and distribute resources for stabilization - Number of district and federal level entities with recruited staff to support stabilization efforts

comment.narrative: 5 Caretaker Administrations deployed
- Systems in place to allocate and distribute resources for stabilization - 5 district and 1 federal level entities with recruited staff to support stabilization efforts

11- The financial procedures for the distribution of resources which were included as an annex of the project document have been reviewed and adjusted to project implementation reality. Payments are being made to 11 districts.
24 district staff - At district level, 11 CLOs (F: 2; M: 9) and 13 LGAs (F: 1; M: 12), 1 of each for each target district, were recruited and trained in 13 districts
5 staff (F:2; M:3) at MoIFA (FGS) level were recruited and are operational.
